awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Near-Field Imaging for Nanoscale Visualization of Exciton-Plasmon Energy Transfer
awd_abstract_narration:
With support from the Chemical Measurement and Imaging Program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Habteyes at the University of New Mexico (UNM) is developing a new type of light microscope that is suited for measuring how light interacts among small particles on a surface within a few nanometers (one-billionth of a meter).  This type of measurements provides new information to understand how small particles interact with each other and how to control light flow. It also helps to develop new materials for solar energy harvesting and environmental monitoring. Professor Habteyes is working with young scientists together on his interdisciplinary scientific research projects, including students from Highland High School over summer months. Professor Habteyes actively recruits students from the historically underrepresented groups to his lab and is developing new hands-on experiments for the undergraduate chemistry courses he teaches at UNM.

Professor Habteyes develops a new type of super-resolution optical microscope that is referred to as near-field excitation and near-field detection (NFED). The new microscope allows him to investigate the interaction between excitonic semiconductor and plasmonic metal nanoscale materials by mapping the surface plasmon modes induced by exciton-plasmon energy transfer. Using the unique capability of the NFED technique and semiconductor quantum dots (QDs) and metal nanostructures (MNSs) as model excitonic and plasmonic systems, he is working on understanding and controlling the behavior of self-assembled QDs that are coupled with plasmonic MNSs, investigating QD-MNS interaction by determining the exciton-plasmon energy transfer efficiency, separating the energy transfer process from other competing excitation decay channels, and understanding and optimizing interface properties so that the exciton-plasmon interaction is maximized and long range energy transfer can be achieved in conjugated excitonic and plasmonic materials. The coupling between excitonic and plasmonic materials promises enhanced light-matter interaction, control of photon emission, and creation of new metamaterials properties that do not exist in nature. Students working on this project are expected to learn broad set of skills, ranging from design and integration of nanomaterials to the development of state-of-the-art novel super-resolution near-field scanning optical microscopes. Professor Habteyes is also actively engaged in outreach to recruit STEM students from the underrepresented local groups.

por.por_cntn:
This interdisciplinary research project has resulted in fundamental understanding of interaction between nanoscale materials and molecular systems with the nanoscale materials particularly plasmonic nanoparticles that enhances light-matter interaction. The scientific finds are summarized as follows.  

  1. Charge transfer plasmon resonances that are insensitive to nanoparticle size are discovered when colloidal gold nanoparticles are directly coupled to gold film (ACS Photonics 2018, 5, 4022-4029). This experimental finding has been informative that surface ligands do not provide complete isolation when colloidal metal nanoparticles are brought in contact with conductive surfaces. 
  2. Through atomic control of dielectric spacing between colloidal gold nanorods (AuNRs) and gold film, abrupt  transition of plasmonic responses have been discovered when the plasmonic interaction transitions from capacitive to the quantum tunneling regime at gap length smaller than 0.5 nm (ACS Photonics 2020, 7, 622-629). This was made possible using AuNR-on-mirror (RoM) nanocavities that has broadly tunable resonance allowing studies of optomechanical coupling interaction in the near-infrared regime.  
  3. By coupling plasmonic nanoparticles with semiconductor heterostructures, the temperature dependence of absorption and emission plasmonic enhancement factors has been quantified (ACS Applied Electronic Materials 2019, 1, 1439-1448). The results indicate that the plasmonic nanoparticles can be used as optical probes to study charge carrier diffusion and efficiency of carrier capture by the emitter.
  4. Through careful analysis of molecule–plasmon excitation coupling, we have successfully determined the electronic transition bands of organic dyes adsorbed on metal surfaces (J. Phys. Chem. Lett. 2020, 3507-3514).
  5. The importance of plasmon enhanced electronic excitation of adsorbates in plasmon driven photochemistry has been highlighted in invited Feature Article (J. Phys. Chem. C 2019, 123, 8469-8483). The analysis in this article highlights the importance of considering plasmon pumped adsorbate electronic excitation as well as the adsorption geometry and surface ligands that can change the reaction pathways.
  6. We have systematically demonstrated that the mechanism of plasmon driven photochemistry depends sensitively on surface-molecule proximity and orientation, where the presence of surface ligands can switch the mechanism from charge transfer to adsorbate electronic excitation (J. Phys. Chem. C 2020, 124, 22711-22720). High degree of product selectivity has been achieved by switching the mechanism from charge transfer to adsorbate electronic excitation.
  7. In an invited Perspective Article published in the Journal of Physical Chemistry, the PI Habteyes has highlighted that, in many cases, the role of metal to molecule electron transfer is limited to forming anionic intermediates that creates accessible excited states at visible wavelengths (J. Phys. Chem. C 2020, 124, 26554–26564). The analysis makes a connection between the well-known mechanisms of gas phase photochemistry of cluster anions and the less-known mechanism of photocatalysis on metal surfaces. 
  8. Using poly(4-vinylpyridine) (P4VP) as model system, the sensitivity of s-SNOM ((scattering-type scanning near-field optical microscopy) in vibrational chemical imaging of organic thin films has been studied systematically (J. Phys. Chem. C 2020, 124, 21018-21026). By fabricating the P4VP film with about 7° angle of elevation, the chemical contrast due to the ring stretching vibration of the polymer as a function of sample thickness has been compared on different substrates.
  9. S-SNOM chemical imaging has been successfully applied for discovering hierarchical self-assembly in polymer blend (J. Phys. Chem. C 2022, 126, 17, 7764–7772). The results indicate that self-assembly of polymers driven by intermolecular and intramolecular interactions leads to rich structural variations that may be manipulated for different applications.

10.  Using s-SNOM chemical imaging and Nano-FTIR (Fourier transform infrared) Spectroscopy, intersubband polaritons have been observed at the level of single nanoantenna for the first time in collaboration with scientists in Los Alamos National Laboratory and Sandia National Laboratories (Nano Letters 2019, 19, 4620-4626). The field localization on the infrared antenna is identified by mapping the electric field using s-SNOM and a broadband IR pulse is used for spectral analysis of the evanescent fields on the nanoantenna surface. By repeating the experiment on multiple infrared antenna with different sizes, spectral splitting of the nanoantenna resonance peak into two polariton modes on the dispersion curve. The experimental approach approach paves a new way of investigating polariton states that results from strong coupling on individual nanoantenna with spatial resolution on the order of 10 nm.

 

The research project has provided training opportunities to eight graduate students, nine undergraduate students, six high school students and two high school science teachers. Three undergraduate students have co-authored peer-reviewed articles. A High School Incoming Senior Research (HSISR) program has been inaugurated in the summer of 2022 involving five students in immersive summer research experience for six weeks working for six hours a day in the lab. The success of the program has been highlighted in the UNM News as well as local news:

New program provides high school students with immersive experience in high-tech research: UNM Newsroom
